content.description: Wiggle, wedge, and face climb up the wide crack. The bulges are the cruxes where the crack goes from 4" to 9 or more inches in places.
content.protection: Gear to 7", optionally larger.
content.location: The offwidth directly right of "Slim and Curvy"

content.description:
The name says it all, the rock quality on this pitch is absolute garbage. If you've climbed all the sweet finger cracks in the area and want to scratch up your new #6, you might want to consider climbing this route. Maybe. The exit moves are kinda fun. Be careful of the jumbled blocks at the top out.

(Added later by another user: There is a bolted chain anchor below the roof, so you don't have to top out through scary loose blocks and belay with no anchor.)
content.protection:
doubles 2-4, 1ea 1,5,6.

There is a single bolt anchor at the very top of the wall. Belay from here and rap off another route or walk off.
content.location: The widening OW in the alcove capped with a roof.

content.description:
A short but excellent jam crack.

Jam the crack which starts at 3" it will narrow down and then widen to a short OW pod.

Lots of good feet.
content.protection:
Pro to 4"

Bolted anchor shared with 272 and the elders.
content.location:
Right of lingerie, right of the elders.

Far right of the trio of routes. (272, elders, theresas)

content.description: I would give this 4 stars, but is that allowed at frenchman ? It was so refreshing to get on some solid rock after my obscure adventures.
content.protection: mostly finger size, but small to #3 is good, many in the .4, .5 size. no anchor, good trad options at top.
content.location: this is the right side of the column that has FIST.

climbs.name: Spank my Ass and call me Sally

content.description:
this looked good, but the lower half was so bad it is hard to recommend the good looking upper half. Maybe if the lower half was cleaned up and a couple of bolts added.

I thought it was harder than 10c given in the book, but it was very dirty.
content.protection: There is one fixed pin at the top of this. the pro is mostly in the finger size and mostly lacking in general. you can make a trad anchor at the top with a #.75, #1, #2. Rap off Freak of the week to the west.
content.location: It is hard to describe where this is, there is a large sort of horn sticking out at the top that divides this from Closet Catamite on the right.

content.description:
harder than the 5.10b given in the book.

multiple 5.11 crux moves and thin hard gear placements
content.protection:
starts out wider, goes super thin at the top. maybe 2) #2, #1, #.75 down lower, then thin wires, tiny cams and ball nuts. no anchor. Good gear anchor options on top in the 1/2" range.

Freak of the week bolted anchor 4' to the right.
content.location: 2nd crack left of Freak of the week.

content.description:
Short n' curvy makes for a fun ride!

Start with 10 feet of tricky climbing, stemming and  finger crack up to a jug. Follow the now mostly 5.9 hand and finger crack through some fun bulges and stemming sections for another 50 feet before moving left to the bolt and sling anchor. This anchor could use some chains.
content.protection: light rack to 2"
content.location: When approaching from the main parking area this climb is in an area before the Desert Dessert alcove. It is easy to spot being just left of a column with six bolts and an anchor (Creeping Death 11.b)  The Anchor on S&C is a nest of brightly colored slings.

content.description: Climb face to 2"-3" crack to ledge. From ledge climb double cracks which begin wide and pinch down to fingers and hands.
content.protection: Gear to 4"
content.location: Far end of the middle east wall. A clean handcrack leads to a ledge with a double crack system above.

content.description:
Although the crack looks splitter from below, the abundance of face holds and stems makes it difficult to climb in good jam fashion. Although a bit contrived, it is more interesting to only jam and to not stem over to Lingerie (this way it actually feels like 10.a).

Either way, fun climb.

Use chain anchor to the right, above Lingerie.
content.protection: rack to 3"
content.location: just right of Savage Heart, left of Lingerie in a right facing corner.

content.description:
Not your typical Coulee bolt job...

Awkward balancy moves and long reaches past three bolts, a small run-out and some so-so climbing above past three more bolts leads to the same finish as Left Out (5.9 trad) and an optional gear placement or a decent run-out below the anchor.

Shares bolted anchor with Left Out.
content.protection: six bolts and a small stopper at the top.
content.location: 1st bolted line right of Desert Dessert.

climbs.name: Peeing with a Boner
climbs.fa: Z. Sinner, A. Sinner, A. Hanson

content.description: Great new route bolted and cleaned on 12/2/17 by a talented north Idaho climber.  Previously listed as an open project in the Yoder and Ford guide, this route now stands alone as one of Vantages best sport routes.  The rock is bomber for the difficulties on the first half and should clean up quickly on the top section.
content.protection: 7 quick draws and a chain anchor, stick clip highly recommended for the start but the rest of the clips are easy
content.location: This is the thin corner left of Crazy Fingers.

climbs.name: Mr. Gorbonifar
climbs.fa: Russ Johnson, Byron Bloomquist, Jeannot Poirot, 1987

content.description:
This may be the best offwidth in Vantage by far. It’s clean, sustained, and offers a range of widths that keeps you thinking.

Start atop a small ledge in the right-facing corner. The crack begins with some fists, but quickly turns into butterflies and hand-fist stacks. Unless you have small knees, you won’t be able to get into the crack for a solid knee jam until it widens a bit further.

Once inside, work your way up the ever-widening crack through some minor waves before getting into the three large squeeze chimney waves toward the top.

The location of the crux is somewhat body dependent. Most will be fine down low and again up high once into the squeeze chimney section, but will find the middle section challenging. If you’re solid making progress on knee scums, then maybe the two largest waves in the chimney will be your crux.

This offwidth is perfect for bumping the bigger cams with only a few sections up top that requires a pull and re-placement above you.

There are chains to the left of the top of the crack that you can get to so you don’t have to top out through the loose blocks above. If you’re setting up a top rope, then leave a piece in (BD #8 or equivalent) at the top to redirect the rope.

The original rating for this route is 5.9 and that’s what’s in the current guidebook, but compared to Wide and Curvy 5.9 (an offwidth right next door) from the same FA team, this is easily a grade higher. I am posting it as a 5.10a/b to be consistent with the softer grading that is prevalent in this area. If enough people climb it and rate it differently, then I will update the page.
content.protection: Gear from 4-12”. BD #4-8 or equivalent. There are also a few decent Big Bro placements in the #1-3 range.
content.location: The beautiful wavy crack in the right-facing corner just left of Coup d’Etat 5.11a and Human Sacrifice 5.10c.

content.description:
MF Snowboarder is a great warmup route at the Middle East wall.  The Select guidebook only gives this one star, which is presumably due to the original route going all of the way to the rim.

Begin 5 feet right of 'Jihad' and scramble up a small pedestal to a very nice rattly finger crack in chocolate rock.  Jam this crack as it widens to thin hands, with the usual Vantage stemming and barn-door foot jamming.  A short pod and some slightly blocky climbing will get you to the anchors.

Overall the rock quality is very good for Vantage, but it still is Vantage so be a little careful.

The original finish involves climbing above the anchors over a few steep, not 100% but not super-loose blocks.  On top, there are a couple bolts in random blocks, set back pretty far from the edge.  Bring long webbing for this option, or just stop at the end of the good climbing where a nice set of bolted anchors gets you back down easily.
content.protection: Typical vantage rack from thin fingers to big hands, with an emphasis on off-fingers to thin hands (ie .5 Camalots to #1 Camalots).  Large stoppers, and likely hexes, work pretty well in the featured crack.  New bolted anchors instead of climbing the last bit of chossy rock, only to ponder how best to get back to the base....  Less is more in this case, indeed.
content.location: MF Snowboarder starts in an off fingers crack above a small pedestal, one crack to the right of 'Jihad' and just to the left of the detached column sport route 'Desert Dessert'.

content.description:
There must be some story behind this route, because in the same year these two did a bolted route in the same place that was called Pudding Time that was chopped. As I was climbing it, it was obvious that some of the bolts could have been not placed near a crack, but in other spots where it would be very hard to protect it would be nice to have a bolt, and the anchor was chopped. So I added a anchor, but it is still very hard to protect in some places. Now this cracks me up because trad people chop bolts, but on trad climbs where the crack is thin, there are sometimes many pitons, including many on the Middle East wall itself.

It is 10d in the book, but I thought in comparison to other 10d's and 11a's it was technically tricky and crazy burly for 10d.

I would give this route 3 stars for climbing especially the roof moves, it is just fucked up at the moment.

I did some cleaning on this and it is less chossy now on the lower part, the upper half is solid rock.
content.protection: mostly very small pro up to #2 mostly small nuts, and peckers might be good.
content.location: several routes right of Superfund

content.description:
I am not entirely sure this was in fact the crack I climbed, hard to tell when you enter obscure unclimbed terrain. It looked promising and turns out to has a ton of rotten crumbling rock. I was thinking it 5.8 but could have a move of 5.9.

Not recommended
content.protection: mostly hand crack. There are a few spots that are wider and full of loose rock. If someone feels like cleaning some more, please do.
content.location: maybe 400' west of Focal Point, the obvious last bolted route. I will try to better describe this after next visit.

content.description:
Spectacular finger crack!

The first 25 feet are insecure and pumpy with delicate footwork. Above the locks improve greatly and it is possible to reast via stemming over to Sex Party. It's not over though....

Chain anchor.
content.protection: rack to 1" mostly small cams and nuts.
content.location: Right of Sex Party.

content.description:
Climb hand crack to the left of

Savage Heart

.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5"

content.description:
An interesting crack climb just left of Desert Dessert.

Start in a steep finger crack which widens slightly before switching cracks to the right (crux) and finishing on hand crack with some loose rock and face holds.

Bolted anchor.
content.protection: Mostly small tcu's. Crux is small stoppers and micro cams, a hand sized piece for higher up but nothing bigger than 2".
content.location: between Human Sacrifice (bolted 10.c) and Desert Dessert (bolted 11.a)

content.description:
Best rock in the Coulee?

Worth doing several times, this gem is pure fun.

Start in a stellar 1" hand crack for the first 15 feet before clipping the first bolt and moving onto   the face. Use both sides of the column and aretes up to a thought provoking crux move.
content.protection: 1" cam and 5 bolts to a chain anchor
content.location: Left of Desert Dessert and Jihad obvious crack to bolted face.

content.description: Average quality for Vantage, a little loose rock and not nearly as good as it's neighbor
content.protection: Lots of small gear: placed lots of small aliens and stoppers
content.location: Crack to the right of Focal Point

content.description:
Start up a dihedral like feature face climbing and using the very thin crack for protection.

Pull over the roof  which will deposit you on a small ledge.

From this ledge continue up very sound rock climbing the thin crack to anchors.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5". Small/Micro cams may be useful
content.location: Before you hit the "main" part of the wall look for a small roof leading to a very thin crack with a chain anchor on top.

content.description:
This one takes some thinking and looking around, just don't look too long!

Use both sides of the colmn for a sustained ride to a cryptic crux near the top. A bit of lichen just for spice!
content.protection: 8 bolts and a fixed pin to a chain anchor
content.location: Next alcove to the right from Desert Dessert.

climbs.name: Fist for Pleasure and for Profit

content.description: I have been walking by this for years and it has always said to me climb me it is worth it. It is worth it.
content.protection:
the lower part is hard to protect and somewhat chossy, but the upper half protects well, and the obvious upper part is fists like the name implies, so #3- #4's. Also tape is recommended or crack gloves.

No anchor, but good gear anchor and rap off close by bolted anchor of Freak of the week to the west.
content.location: this stands out with the swooping splitter top portion on the left ( east) side of a curving column just right of a bushy tree in the alcove below the trail.

content.description: Thin crack and stemming route with a couple of reasonable bonus moves mid-pitch. Good friction.
content.protection: Several good small-medium nut placements available at the start, then several good small cam placements follow (for example Metolius small yellows and blues, 2X each.) I managed to place a #2 gold camalot in a little pod, but not sure where a #3 would go.(?) A white-painted pin makes thin moves mid-pitch feel cozy. The line is climbable directly up to a point level with the Focal Point anchors; optionally use a long sling to clip a bolt and/or piton around the arete. Alternatively, sneak over to Focal Point at the bolt/pin to avoid the last couple of stemming moves. Use Focal Point anchors.
content.location: Directly left of Focal Point.

content.description: Climb the inward flaring crack which provides excellent jams due to the inward flare of the crack. There are also some solid face holds.
content.protection:
Gear to 4"

Bolted Anchor
content.location: Between 272 and Theresas.

content.description:
Very thin, very dirty, very run-out.

I will have to try it again, I was not very inspired to clean this, but if it were cleaned and a few bolts added it could be good, or it could just be top roped. Good .75 and #1 for anchor at top.
content.protection: very small to non existent. there is a fixed pin at the top, but not the 3 like it used to have
content.location: the right side of the alcove that has the bushy tree, the left side of the arete, the left side of the column that has Merry Bullman.

climbs.name: Desert Dessert
climbs.fa: Jim Yoder, Kevin Buselmier and Marlene Ford 93'

content.description:
This is the free standing pillar with a striking green streaked face and clean double arete profile.

An area classic that should not be missed.

Start on the left side of the pillar climbing the left-hand arete, move right onto the face for a bit then out to the right-hand arete for a while then back left again below the anchor. Airy, technical, and exciting!
content.protection: bolts
content.location: Middle Section

content.description: Obvious bolt route next to Wide and Curvy going up the column.  Felt awkward and difficult to clip the first two bolts.  Didn't find a straight up path and basically started with one foot on Wide and Curvy.  Sustained with cryptic route finding; couple enjoyable moves. Despite the three star rating in the guide, it isn't as fun as the other excellent sport routes on the wall.
content.protection: 6 bolts and chain anchor
content.location: Bolt route that shares anchors with Wide and Curvy

content.protection:
Gear to 3"

Can finish on bolted anchor to the right.
content.location:
Far right side of the middle section of the middle east wall.

Starts in a thin crack with a lot of face holds.

Mostly face climbing with some jams.

content.description: A fun and interesting crack if you have done all the area classics already. It was pretty clean because the rock in this alcove is sound compared to most of the rest of this wall. It starts with chimney moves, some wide, and then mostly thin to too thin for fingers, with some good stemming options and face climbing on HS.
content.protection: mostly small gear up to #3 if you chimney climb up the start unprotected. No anchor, I was planning to add one but the HS anchor seems close enough. The climbing above there is fun, but the huge loose blocks deter from the goodness.
content.location: The right side crack of Human Sacrifice column.

content.description:
this is given as 10b in the book and just as hard as Spank to me. While more fun to climb and slightly easier to protect, it has some super hard moves that are way harder than 10b. The super hard moves are especially hard to protect.

I did a little cleaning on this, but the lower half is very chossy.
content.protection:
mostly in the finger size- up to #1, one fixed pin, anchor at the top .5, .75, #1, #2.

Rap off Freak of the week to the west - a cairn there.
content.location:
the wall tends to have inny and outy sections, this is on a outer buttress and there are alcoves on either side, on the left is Fist for Pleasure and further right is Butcher of Baghdad.

on the right side of a column that has the giant horn at the top.

content.description: A highly technical route on beautiful, yellow-splotched rock that follows a thin seam with flaring finger locks and arete to a small roof. Pull the roof with some trickery and clip the chains from a jug.
content.protection: Eight bolts to chains.
content.location: Bolted line that starts on a pedestal just right of Aftershock.

content.description:
One of the first sport routes you come to on the middle east wall. Starts with a boulder problem involving a large dead point to a descent hold. Afterwards, continue up the much easier arête to the chains.

As a fall at the crux would lead to a hairy ground fall on to sharp rocks, pre-clipping the first bolt is recommended
content.protection: bolts to chains
content.location: The first bolted lines as you walk towards the middle east wall. Look for the oversized metolius hangar above a talus field.

content.description: Nice route with interesting movement and good rests for gear placement. Great addition for the 5.11 trad climber.  Some loose rock but generally solid for Vantage and protects well.
content.protection: Two sets of cams below 1 inch and stoppers
content.location: First crack to the left of Jihad

content.description: Technical stemming mixed with small handholds make up most of the pitch. the last twenty feet offer the real test of trickery.
content.protection: 8 bolts and chain anchors.
content.location:
A couple hundred feed to the left of the Dessert Desert.

At eye level, some seams in the rock create an "A" shape. Also note a curved rock at the base shaped like a corn chip.

content.description:
Offwidth/face climb up the first 15 feet of this route to a good rest (5.8). Then stem, jam and face climb up the next 25 feet to the ledge and anchor. (5.6)

The right crack starts very thin and ends at 1.5 inches, the left crack starts at 5 inches and pinches down as you go.
content.protection:
Pro to 5"

You would be totally fine without the 5. YMMV.

Bolted anchor to the right
content.location: Right of lingerie, look for the short wide crack that ends on a ledge.
